posts.name:
Kiran Babu
Kiran Babu
posts.content:
Today, I saw the future of workplace well-being in action

HR isn't about policies anymore.

We stopped measuring turnover and time-to-hire.
Now we track employee satisfaction, mental health program uptake, and work-life balance.

The result?

â†³ 47% reduction in stress-related leave
â†³ 3x increase in employee engagement scores
â†³ 89% of employees report feeling supported

The key wasn't adding more programs.

It was LISTENING to what our people needed.
No more one-size-fits-allâ€”flexibility and understanding of personal situations.

These numbers tell a story.
But the real magic is in the moments we can't measure:
Seeing people energized, creative, and present at work because they know we care.

What HR metric do you think deserves more attention, and why?

comments.commentText: Incredible transformation! Prioritizing listening over metrics creates a supportive culture.  Iâ€™d love to see a focus on resilience as a key metric!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this approach! Listening to employees is key. Iâ€™d highlight psychological safetyâ€”its crucial for innovation and engagement!

posts.name:
Josh Matthews
Josh Matthews
posts.content:
Trust is the foundation of any strong team, and at Salesforce Staffing, we believe it starts with leadership. The strength and quality of your team are a direct reflection of you as a leader.

If trust within your team isn't where you want it to be, consider implementing strategies that foster an environment of trust and mutual respect:

- Be transparent: Open communication is key. Share your vision, and be honest about challenges.
- Show appreciation: Recognize hard work and achievements. Everyone wants to feel valued.
- Encourage autonomy: Empower your team members by trusting them with responsibilities, but always be ready to offer your support.
- Listen and act: Actively listen to feedback and show that you value input by making changes when necessary.
- Lead by example: Maintain integrity in all your actions. Your team will follow your lead.

Iâ€™ll leave you with this: How would your life change if confidence in your team was 100%?

comments.commentText: Absolutely agree! Trust transforms teams. By fostering it through transparency and appreciation, we can elevate our collective potential!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Trust truly transforms teams. Implementing these strategies can create a powerful ripple effect in any organization. ğŸ’ª #Leadership #Teamwork

posts.name:
Sumit Mishra
Sumit Mishra
posts.content:
If you can't handle stress, you can't handle success.

We've all heard this phrase before, and while it might sound a bit harsh, thereâ€™s a deeper truth nestled within those words.

Stress is a part of life, especially in our fast-paced, goal-driven world. But how we respond to it can shape our journey toward success.

Think about it: every challenge we face, each tight deadline, and those moments of uncertainty are opportunitiesâ€”albeit stressful onesâ€”to grow.

Itâ€™s in those stressful moments that we learn resilience, adaptability, and a deeper understanding of ourselves.

Success isnâ€™t just about reaching the finish line; itâ€™s about navigating the hurdles along the way.

So, how do we build our stress-handling toolkit? Here are a few strategies that have helped me:

Mindfulness: Take a moment to breathe and ground yourself. â€ï¸ Whether itâ€™s a few deep breaths or a quick walk, find what helps you reset.

Perspective: View challenges as stepping stones rather than roadblocks. Each setback is just a setup for a comeback!

Support Network: Surround yourself with people who uplift you. Sharing your stress can lighten the load. 

Self-Care: Prioritize your well-being. A well-rested mind is far better equipped to tackle challenges.

Remember, itâ€™s not about eliminating stress but learning to navigate it with grace.

So, the next time you feel the pressure, embrace it as a sign that youâ€™re on the path to something great.

comments.commentText: Great insights! Embracing stress as a growth opportunity is key. Mindfulness and support make all the difference on the journey to success!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing stress as a growth opportunity truly transforms challenges into stepping stones towards success. Thanks for sharing!

posts.name:
Zachary Wright MBA
Zachary Wright MBA
posts.content:
Letâ€™s call it what it is: Ignorance.

I spent four hours watching the GOP Oversight hearing on Remote Work (Thanks,â€¦I think ). One thing was crystal clear:

The people arguing against remote work donâ€™t even understand what it is.
- Remote work â‰  Work from home.
- Return to office â‰  Return to work.

And yet, theyâ€™re making sweeping claims and decisions about the future of work without knowing the basics.

Letâ€™s hit them with the facts:
1ï¸âƒ£ Remote workers are 47% more productive than in-office employees. (Stanford)
2ï¸âƒ£ Flexible work reduces attrition by 35%. (Owl Labs)
3ï¸âƒ£ Hybrid & remote setups save employees 72 minutes daily, most of which goes back into work. (HBR)

Still think remote work is the problem?

Itâ€™s not. The problem is outdated leaders blaming remote work to avoid confronting their own ignorance about what actually makes teams productive:

1) Trust over micromanagement.
2) Intentional work design.
3) Systems that empower employees to do their best workâ€”no matter where they are.

If youâ€™re against remote work but canâ€™t define it, maybe you shouldnâ€™t be deciding its future.

Ignorance isnâ€™t a strategy. Data-driven, forward-thinking leadership is. So, letâ€™s stop scapegoating remote work and focus on fixing whatâ€™s really broken.

Whatâ€™s your take, do leaders need a crash course on remote work before making decisions?

comments.commentText:
Absolutely agree! Leadership should embrace data and understanding over outdated perceptions. Itâ€™s time to prioritize trust and flexibility! 
hashtag
#FutureOfWork

Jon Leslie  they do call it telework. Which isnâ€™t technically wrong. Might show how outdated policy is or how the policy makers havenâ€™t updated their terminology to match the current situation of work.

posts.name:
Cristian Mudure
Cristian Mudure
posts.content:
4-day workweek, 100% remote work... I find the discussion increasingly exhausting.

First, every company has the right to define how it wants to operate. And people are free to decide whether they want to work under those conditions or not.

If a company struggles to attract new employees, it will have to reconsider whether its approach is the right one. On the other hand, if Iâ€™ve been unemployed for a long time, I also need to question whether my expectations might be too high.

No one is entitled to anything; in the end, the market decides.

A deal between adults.

comments.commentText: 'exhausting' is a very polite way of saying 'boring'.

posts.commentAdded: Agreed! Its all about finding the right fit for both companies and candidates. Flexibility and open dialogue are key! #WorkCulture

posts.name:
Gabe Pankonin
Gabe Pankonin
posts.content:
Always iterating

When I asked how AI would be added to AscendTMS,went into great detail about 'maintaining' vs 'innovating' or 'iterating' in the software space.

In the clip, he discusses how Ascend has already rewritten the entire system once over in the past 8 years and will likely rewrite the entire system again over the next 5-8 years

AI will be a part of that newer system

My take? I bet AI is a part of writing that new code in addition to being a feature in the new TMS

And I bet the entire system is rewritten in 3 years instead of 8

That goes for all TMS software in the space these days. AI will not only be a native feature at some point, AI will be writing the code as more than just a Co-Pilot

The real question to pose based on that hypothesis is whether VC funds will finally stop pouring money into the TMS space becuase the cost to build and barrier for entry will continue to plummet.

If so, that is good news for the bootstrappers who have to compete against the mountain of VC funded brands in the space currently!
posts.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Its fascinating to see how AI is reshaping not just features, but the very foundation of TMS. Looking forward to the evolution!
